Â¿Nos estamos quedando sin datos para entrenar la IA? ğŸ¤”

SÃ­, como lo oÃ­s.  Empresas como OpenAI y X (antes Twitter) afirman que nos estamos quedando sin datos del mundo real para entrenar modelos de IA. Â¡Incluso Musk dice que agotamos el conocimiento humano acumulado en el entrenamiento de IA el aÃ±o pasado! ğŸ¤¯

La soluciÃ³n que se estÃ¡ usando masivamente (y que parece mÃ¡s barata): datos sintÃ©ticos.  Es decir, datos generados por la propia IA.

Pero... Â¡ojo! ğŸ‘€  Los datos sintÃ©ticos tambiÃ©n tienen desventajas.  Imaginad que alimentamos a una IA con fotos de comida generadas por otra IA.  Al final, tendremos una IA "chef" que solo sabe cocinar platos que existen solo en el mundo digital, platos que nadie ha probado ni puede probar.  Algo parecido pasa con el entrenamiento de la IA en general.  Si la alimentamos con datos sintÃ©ticos con sesgos, la IA los heredarÃ¡ y amplificarÃ¡, comprometiendo su funcionalidad y llevÃ¡ndola al "colapso del modelo", haciÃ©ndola menos creativa.

Es como si un pintor solo aprendiera a pintar copiando cuadros de otros pintores que a su vez copiaron cuadrosâ€¦  Al final, se pierde la esencia, la creatividad y la conexiÃ³n con la realidad.  El resultado: cuadros tÃ©cnicamente perfectos pero sin alma.

La construcciÃ³n es un sector muy poco digitalizado, por lo fÃ­sico de su naturaleza. Tal vez tampoco necesite mucho. Con un lÃ¡piz y un lÃ¡ser se "proyecta" una casa.
Tal vez lo mÃ¡s digital del proyecto fueron los renders que nos hicieron mis queridas Silvia y Raquel para que yo, el analfabeto de la construcciÃ³n, fuera capaz de visualizar algo de lo que Ã­bamos a hacer antes de meternos en semejante follÃ³n.

La gestiÃ³n de los imprevistos. Wow. Â¿CuÃ¡ntas cosas se pueden torcer cada dÃ­a? Algo que se rompe, otra cosa que no llega, una viga que aparece de la nada para trastocarte los planes, bajantes que no existen. Menuda cintura hay que tener para este mundillo!

original_content:
La ganadora de 3 Oscars, The Brutallist, ha sido enormemente criticada por su uso de la IA en la ediciÃ³n:
Much of the filmâ€™s dialogue is in Hungarian, the filmmakers went to great lengths to make it as accurate to a native speaker as possible. This included judicious use of AI from the Ukrainian specialist Respeecher.

JancsÃ³ explains, â€œI am a native Hungarian speaker and I know that it is one of the most difficult languages to learn to pronounce. Even with Adrien's Hungarian background - (Brodyâ€™s mother is a Hungarian refugee who emigrated to the U.S in 1956) - it's not that simple. Itâ€™s an extremely unique language. We coached [Brody and Felicity Jones] and they did a fabulous job but we also wanted to perfect it so that not even locals will spot any difference.â€

Tweaks were needed to enhance specific letters of their vocal sounds. â€œIf youâ€™re coming from the Anglo-Saxon world certain sounds can be particularly hard to grasp. We first tried to ADR these harder elements with the actors. Then we tried to ADR them completely with other actors but that just didnâ€™t work. So we looked for other options of how to enhance it.â€

Brody and Jones were fully onboard with the process guided by Respeecher which started with recording their voices to drive the AI Hungarian delivery. JancsÃ³ also fed his voice into the AI model to finesse the tricky dialect.

â€œMost of their Hungarian dialogue has a part of me talking in there. We were very careful about keeping their performances. It's mainly just replacing letters here and there. You can do this in ProTools yourself, but we had so much dialogue in Hungarian that we really needed to speed up the process otherwise we'd still be in post.â€

GenAI is also used right at the end of the film in a sequence at the Venice Biennale to conjure a series of architectural drawings and finished buildings in the style of the fictional architect.  The overall effect is so impressive you might find yourself headed to Wikipedia to double check that LÃ¡szlÃ³ TÃ³th existed.

â€œIt is controversial in the industry to talk about AI, but it shouldn't be,â€ he acknowledges. â€œWe should be having a very open discussion about what tools AI can provide us with. Thereâ€™s nothing in the film using AI that hasn't been done before. It just makes the process a lot faster. We use AI to create these tiny little details that we didn't have the money or the time to shoot.â€

For more on this angle, read our follow up post here.

El director,  JancsÃ³ (hÃºngaro nativo),  explica que incluso con el background hÃºngaro de Brody,  necesitaban retoques para que ni los locales notaran la diferencia.  Primero probaron con ADR (doblaje adicional) con los actores e incluso con otros actores, pero no funcionÃ³.  AsÃ­ que la IA al rescate ğŸš€

Pero ojo ğŸ‘€,  no solo usaron IA para el idioma.  TambiÃ©n la usaron para generar dibujos arquitectÃ³nicos al final de la pelÃ­cula, Â¡y el resultado es tan ğŸ” que te dan ganas de buscar en Wikipedia si el arquitecto ficticio existe!

JancsÃ³ dice que el tema de la IA no deberÃ­a ser tabÃº, y que hay que hablar abiertamente de las herramientas que nos ofrece.  En este caso, la usaron para pulir detallitos que, por tiempo o presupuesto,  no podÃ­an rodar.

original_content:
Â¿Nos quedamos sin datos para la IA?
El post debe reflexionar sobre la situaciÃ³n inminente de falta de datos para la IA a la que nos enfrentamos, y sus posibles implicaciones y soluciones, como que DeepSeek se haya entrenado en parte con datos de O1 de OpenAI.
Elon Musk concurs with other AI experts that thereâ€™s little real-world data left to train AI models on.

â€œWeâ€™ve now exhausted basically the cumulative sum of human knowledge â€¦ in AI training,â€ Musk said during a livestreamed conversation with Stagwell chairman Mark Penn on X late Wednesday. â€œThat happened basically last year.â€

Musk, who owns AI company xAI, echoed themes former OpenAI chief scientist Ilya Sutskever touched on at NeurIPS, the machine learning conference, during an address in December. Sutskever, who said the AI industry had reached what he called â€œpeak data,â€ predicted a lack of training data will force a shift away from the way models are developed today.

Indeed, Musk suggested that synthetic data â€” data generated by AI models themselves â€” is the path forward. â€œThe only way to supplement [real-world data] is with synthetic data, where the AI creates [training data],â€ he said. â€œWith synthetic data â€¦ [AI] will sort of grade itself and go through this process of self-learning.â€

Other companies, including tech giants like Microsoft, Meta, OpenAI, and Anthropic, are already using synthetic data to train flagship AI models. Gartner estimates 60% of the data used for AI and anÂ­aÂ­lytÂ­ics projects in 2024 were synÂ­thetÂ­iÂ­cally genÂ­erÂ­ated.

Microsoftâ€™s Phi-4, which was open sourced early Wednesday, was trained on synthetic data alongside real-world data. So were Googleâ€™s Gemma models. Anthropic used some synthetic data to develop one of its most performant systems, Claude 3.5 Sonnet. And Meta fine-tuned its most recent Llama series of models using AI-generated data.

Training on synthetic data has other advantages, like cost savings. AI startup Writer claims its Palmyra X 004 model, which was developed using almost entirely synthetic sources, cost just $700,000 to develop â€” compared to estimates of $4.6 million for a comparably sized OpenAI model.

But there as disadvantages as well. Some research suggests that synthetic data can lead to model collapse, where a model becomes less â€œcreativeâ€ â€” and more biased â€” in its outputs, eventually seriously compromising its functionality. Because models create synthetic data, if the data used to train these models has biases and limitations, their outputs will be similarly tainted.

Elon Musk y otros expertos en IA afirman que nos estamos quedando sin datos del mundo real para entrenar modelos de IA.  De hecho, Musk dice que agotamos el conocimiento humano acumulado en el entrenamiento de IA Â¡el aÃ±o pasado! ğŸ¤¯

Â¿La soluciÃ³n? Datos sintÃ©ticos.  Es decir, datos generados por la propia IA.  Empresas como Microsoft, Meta, OpenAI y Anthropic ya los utilizan.  Incluso, la startup Writer afirma haber desarrollado su modelo Palmyra X 004 por solo $700,000 usando casi exclusivamente datos sintÃ©ticos, frente a los $4.6 millones que costarÃ­a un modelo similar de OpenAI.  Â¡Un ahorro considerable!ğŸ’°

Pero... Â¡ojo! ğŸ‘€  Los datos sintÃ©ticos tambiÃ©n tienen desventajas.  Pueden llevar al "colapso del modelo", haciendo que la IA sea menos creativa y mÃ¡s propensa a sesgos, comprometiendo su funcionalidad.  Si los datos usados para entrenar tienen sesgos, la IA los heredarÃ¡.

Este tema me recuerda al post que hice sobre la importancia de analizar TODOS los datos, no solo los "supervivientes" (link al post anterior sobre el aviÃ³n de la segunda guerra mundial).  Al final, la clave estÃ¡ en usar la cabeza.  Al igual que con la IA que genera imÃ¡genes raras de comida,  hay que filtrar y ser crÃ­ticos con los resultados.
